title: Questor share tip: Hill & Smith takes hit on US business
text:
10.13 +3.215 
The industrial engineer stands to benefit from increased spending on the UKs road netowrk, says Questor 
Hill & Smith (Stuttgart: 7HL.SG - news ) 695p+6p Questor says HOLD 
Hill & Smith [LON:HILS] the engineering group that specialises in galvanising and other steel products, saw first-half profits more than halve after a US investment went wrong. 
However, long-term investors should focus on the improving performance in the rest of the business. 
The company paid $45m (£29m) for US-based Paterson Group in March 2011. Management has now admitted that trading and profits are nowhere near the levels expected and have written off about $25m of the target’s value. 
The charge has been taken in the first-half numbers, causing pre-tax profits to slump to £7.1m, from £16m in the same period last year. 
The price paid for Paterson was a painful mistake, but investors yesterday focused on the strong underlying trading in the business. The shares gained 1pc to 693.4p. 
The company is a specialist steel manufacturer. Drive along any UK motorways and you are likely to see Hill & Smith’s crash barriers. The group saw revenue from its roads business rise 35pc in the first half. This is likely to increase after the Conservative government pledged to spend more on infrastructure. 
About three-quarters of revenue and 85pc of underlying operating profit are generated from its UK and US businesses, which mainly operate in industrial markets, where the outlook is good. After a slow start, infrastructure spending in North America is rapidly accelerating. 
Revenue in the six months to the end of June increased 4pc to £233m, at higher operating profit margins than last year. Taking out the one-off costs, underlying pre-tax profits were up 19pc to £24.8m. 
Market consensus is for full-year, underlying pre-tax profits of about £50.3m, from revenue of £475m, giving 48.5p in earnings per share. 
The shares offer a prospective yield of 2.8pc and have gained 14pc, or almost £1 per share, since we said they looked too cheap (Buy, 603p, March 10). 
Now (NYSE: DNOW - news ) , trading on 14.4 times forecast earnings, they remain a steady income share. 
With trading expected to improve into the second half, we are happy to remain holders.
